column1: This test is ordered to see how much phosphorus is in your blood.

Common causes include: - Diabetic ketoacidosis - Hypoparathyroidism - Kidney failure - Liver disease - Too much vitamin D - Too much phosphate in your diet - Use of certain medications such as phosphate-containing laxatives Lower than normal levels (hypophosphatemia) may be due to: - Alcoholism - Hypercalcemia - Hyperparathyroidism - Too little dietary intake of phosphate - Very poor nutrition - Too little vitamin D, resulting in rickets (childhood) or osteomalacia (adult)
